description: National security laws are expected to sail through Parliament, while an expert suggests helping Australian sectors vulnerable to Chinese political coercion.
text:
LoadingShadow Treasurer said he would work through the detail but Labor was
inclined to support the measures. Council of Australia chief executive
Jennifer Westacott said the changes were sensible given the unprecedented
economic circumstances caused by the coronavirus but warned the government
needed to get "the balance right" to minimise the impact on Australian
companies and jobs."We'll need to ensure that low risk investments are
streamlined and approved quickly," she said.n Premier , the leader of the only
state in Australia tosign onto 's $1.5 trillion Belt and Road infrastructure
initiativeThe changes will apply to all foreign investors but is expected to
come under particular scrutiny after Shenzhen firm Huawei was banned from the
5G network in 2018 over national security concerns. launched trade strikes on
$1 billion worth ofbeefbarleyReplayIn a new submission to a parliamentary
inquiry into diversifying Australia's trade, Charles Sturt University academic
Clive Hamilton said "the historical rupture brought by the virus" was an
opportunity for Australia to reduce its reliance on after the embassy warned
Australian universities, beef and wine could be boycotted by Chinese
consumers. is Australia's largest trading partner and accounts for a third of
all of Australia's exports."This is a well-drilled tactic of the Chinese
Communist Party. In the Party's lexicon it's known as yi shang bi zheng
(literally, 'using business to pressure government')," he said.Professor
Hamilton said the government should identify those sectors of the Australian
economy most prone to the tactics such as wine and tourism. He said Austrade
should help them to diversify and if they ignore warnings - taxpayers should
not bail them out.Professor Hamilton said Australia should also create an
easily accesible FIRB-style database for Chinese investment in the Pacific,
where has significant aid and infrastructure interests.The Director of the
Australia- Relations Institute, James Laurenceson, told the inquiry
diversifying Australia's export markets away from meant diversifying toward
countries that are not willing to pay as much."Meanwhile, any trade
opportunities with that are left on the table would quickly be snapped up by
Australia's international competitors," he said in his submission. "The
combined effect will cost Australians jobs and by weakening the economy will
make Australia less, not more, secure."License this articleEryk BagshawEryk
Bagshaw is the correspondent for and . Due to travel restrictions, he is
currently based in Canberra.Most Viewed in

relations.sentence: LoadingShadow Treasurer said he would work through the detail but Labor was inclined to support the measures.

launched trade strikes on $1 billion worth ofbeefbarleyReplayIn a new submission to a parliamentary inquiry into diversifying Australia's trade, Charles Sturt University academic Clive Hamilton said "the historical rupture brought by the virus" was an opportunity for Australia to reduce its reliance on after the embassy warned Australian universities, beef and wine could be boycotted by Chinese consumers.
Professor Hamilton said the government should identify those sectors of the Australian economy most prone to the tactics such as wine and tourism.
He said Austrade should help them to diversify and if they ignore warnings - taxpayers should not bail them out.
Professor Hamilton said Australia should also create an easily accesible FIRB-style database for Chinese investment in the Pacific, where has significant aid and infrastructure interests.
"Meanwhile, any trade opportunities with that are left on the table would quickly be snapped up by Australia's international competitors," he said in his submission.

"Meanwhile, any trade opportunities with that are left on the table would quickly be snapped up by Australia's international competitors," he said in his submission.

title: New national security changes for foreign investors to pass [Age, The (AU)]
html: LoadingShadow Treasurer said he would work through the detail but Labor was inclined to support the measures. Council of Australia chief executive Jennifer Westacott said the changes were sensible given the unprecedented economic circumstances caused by the coronavirus but warned the government needed to get "the balance right" to minimise the impact on Australian companies and jobs."We'll need to ensure that low risk investments are streamlined and approved quickly," she said.n Premier , the leader of the only state in Australia tosign onto 's $1.5 trillion Belt and Road infrastructure initiativeThe changes will apply to all foreign investors but is expected to come under particular scrutiny after Shenzhen firm Huawei was banned from the 5G network in 2018 over national security concerns. launched trade strikes on $1 billion worth ofbeefbarleyReplayIn a new submission to a parliamentary inquiry into diversifying Australia's trade, Charles Sturt University academic Clive Hamilton said "the historical rupture brought by the virus" was an opportunity for Australia to reduce its reliance on after the embassy warned Australian universities, beef and wine could be boycotted by Chinese consumers. is Australia's largest trading partner and accounts for a third of all of Australia's exports."This is a well-drilled tactic of the Chinese Communist Party. In the Party's lexicon it's known as yi shang bi zheng (literally, 'using business to pressure government')," he said.Professor Hamilton said the government should identify those sectors of the Australian economy most prone to the tactics such as wine and tourism. He said Austrade should help them to diversify and if they ignore warnings - taxpayers should not bail them out.Professor Hamilton said Australia should also create an easily accesible FIRB-style database for Chinese investment in the Pacific, where has significant aid and infrastructure interests.The Director of the Australia- Relations Institute, James Laurenceson, told the inquiry diversifying Australia's export markets away from meant diversifying toward countries that are not willing to pay as much."Meanwhile, any trade opportunities with that are left on the table would quickly be snapped up by Australia's international competitors," he said in his submission. "The combined effect will cost Australians jobs and by weakening the economy will make Australia less, not more, secure."License this articleEryk BagshawEryk Bagshaw is the correspondent for and . Due to travel restrictions, he is currently based in Canberra.Most Viewed in
